answers.a: Microcrystalline wax is a petroleum-derived wax with very small crystals (food additive E905c) used for protective and glazing coatings; it’s related to but distinct from E907 (hydrogenated poly‑1‑decene), a synthetic hydrocarbon wax used as a food glazing agent.

answers.q: how to use renaissance micro crystalline wax polish
answers.a: It isn’t a food additive; apply a very thin coat to a clean, dry surface, let it haze, then buff to a shine—avoid food-contact uses and follow the product’s instructions.

answers.q: renaissance micro-crystalline wax polish how to use
answers.a: Wipe on an extremely thin film with a soft cloth, allow a light haze, then buff; use in ventilation and do not apply to items that will contact food.

answers.q: state why paraffin wax of small crystalline structure is important
answers.a: Fine-crystal (microcrystalline) waxes form tougher, smoother, glossier films that resist cracking and moisture, which improves the performance of food coatings and glazes; hydrocarbon wax glazes such as E907 take advantage of these properties for even, durable finishes.

answers.q: what can you do with renaissance micro crystalline wax polish
answers.a: Use it to protect and add sheen to metals, wood, leather, and stone in conservation or household settings; it isn’t intended for food contact or as a food additive like E907.
